notes: Essential question word for asking about time
notes_bg_to_de: В немски 'wann' се използва за питания за време: 'Wann kommst du?' (Кога идваш?). Не бъркайте с 'wenn' (когато) и 'als' (когато в миналото).
notes_de_to_bg: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Кога' = 'wann'. Verwendet für direkte Zeitfragen. Betonung auf der ersten Silbe: КО-га. Oft kombiniert mit Futur: 'Кога ще дойдеш?' (Wann wirst du kommen?).
etymology: From Proto-Slavic *kogda (when). Related to Russian когда, Polish kiedy
cultural_note: Frequently used in Bulgarian for planning and scheduling. Bulgarians often use it with present tense for future actions: 'Кога тръгваш?' (When are you leaving?)
linguistic_note: Pronunciation: [kɔˈɡa]. Stress on first syllable. Invariable interrogative adverb. Can be used in indirect questions: 'Не знам кога' (I don't know when)

examples.sentence: Не знам кога ще се върна.
examples.translation: Ich weiß nicht, wann ich zurückkomme.

notes: Essential question word for asking about location
notes_bg_to_de: Немското 'wo' пита за местоположение: 'Wo bist du?' (Къде си?). За посока използвайте 'wohin' (накъде) или 'woher' (откъде). Запомнете разликата!
notes_de_to_bg: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Къде' = 'wo'. Fragt nach statischer Position. Betonung: къ-ДЕ (zweite Silbe). Achtung: Bulgarisch hat nur ein Wort 'къде' für Ort, Deutsche unterscheiden wo/wohin/woher.
etymology: From Proto-Slavic *kъde (where, whither). Related to Russian где, куда
cultural_note: Very common in Bulgarian for asking directions or locations. Bulgarians may point or gesture while saying 'къде' to clarify meaning
linguistic_note: Pronunciation: [kɤˈdɛ]. Stress on second syllable. Can mean both 'where' (location) and 'where to' (direction) depending on verb: 'Къде живееш?' vs 'Къде отиваш?'

examples.translation: Ich weiß nicht, wo der Schlüssel ist.

notes: Essential question word for asking about reasons
notes_bg_to_de: В немски има три синонима: 'warum', 'weshalb', 'wieso' - всички означават 'защо'. 'Warum' е най-често срещаното. Отговорете с 'weil' (защото): 'Warum? - Weil...'
notes_de_to_bg: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Защо' = 'warum/weshalb/wieso'. Betonung: за-ЩО (zweite Silbe). Antworten oft mit 'защото' (weil): 'Защо? - Защото...'
cultural_note: Bulgarians use 'защо' frequently in conversation. Children often ask 'Защо?' repeatedly, similar to English 'why?'
linguistic_note: Pronunciation: [zɐˈʃtɔ]. Stress on second syllable. Commonly shortened in speech to [zaʃˈtɔ]. Can begin questions or appear mid-sentence

notes: Essential question word for asking about manner or state
notes_bg_to_de: Немското 'wie' има много употреби: 'Wie geht's?' (Как си?), 'Wie alt?' (На колко години?), 'Wie viel?' (Колко струва?). Често се среща в сравнения: 'so...wie' (толкова...колкото).
notes_de_to_bg: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Как' = 'wie'. Betonung: КАК (einsilbig, betont). Sehr häufig in Grußformeln: 'Как си?' = 'Wie geht's?'. Auch für Vergleiche und Beschreibungen.
etymology: From Proto-Slavic *kako (how, as). Related to Russian как, Polish jak
cultural_note: The phrase 'Как си?' (How are you?) is the most common informal greeting in Bulgaria, even more than 'Здравей'
linguistic_note: Pronunciation: [kak]. Single stressed syllable. Very versatile word - used for manner, comparison, exclamations. Can combine with other words: 'как така' (how so), 'как и' (as well as)

examples.translation: Wie geht's? / Wie geht es dir?

notes: Essential question word for asking about quantity or amount
notes_bg_to_de: Немското 'wie viel' се използва за неброими неща (wie viel Geld?), а 'wie viele' за броими (wie viele Bücher?). В български 'колко' покрива и двете.
notes_de_to_bg: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Колко' = 'wie viel/wie viele'. Betonung: КОЛ-ко. Keine Unterscheidung zwischen zählbar/unzählbar wie im Deutschen. Auch für Alter: 'На колко години си?' (Wie alt bist du?)
etymology: From 'коли-ко', related to количество (quantity). Proto-Slavic origin
cultural_note: Essential for shopping and haggling in Bulgarian markets. Also used for time: 'Колко е часът?' (What time is it?)
linguistic_note: Pronunciation: [ˈkɔɫkɔ]. Stress on first syllable. Can be used with various constructions: 'колко струва' (how much costs), 'колко време' (how much time)

notes: Question word for asking about possession or ownership
notes_bg_to_de: Немското 'wessen' е генитив от 'wer' и се използва рядко в разговор. По-често казвайте 'Wem gehört...?' (На кого принадлежи...?). 'Wessen' звучи формално.
notes_de_to_bg: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Чий' = 'wessen'. Flektiert nach Geschlecht: чий (m), чия (f), чие (n), чии (pl). Beispiel: 'Чия е тази книга?' (Wessen Buch ist das? / Wem gehört dieses Buch?)
etymology: From Proto-Slavic *čьjь (whose). Related to Russian чей, Polish czyj
cultural_note: Used frequently in Bulgarian to establish ownership or identify belongings. More common in everyday speech than German 'wessen'
linguistic_note: Pronunciation: [t͡ʃiɪ̯]. Has four forms agreeing with gender/number of possessed object: чий/чия/чие/чии. The question asks about the possessor, but agrees with the possessed item

notes_bg_to_de: Немското 'ich' винаги се пише с малка буква (освен в началото на изречението), докато в български 'аз' може да се изпуска в разговор, защото глаголната форма е ясна: 'Отивам' (вместо 'Аз отивам').
notes_de_to_bg: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Аз' = 'ich'. Betonung: АЗ (einsilbig). Oft weggelassen im Bulgarischen, da Verben Personen anzeigen: 'съм уморен' (statt 'аз съм уморен'). Aber für Betonung nötig.
etymology: From Proto-Slavic *azъ (I). Related to Russian я, Old Church Slavonic азъ
cultural_note: Bulgarian speakers often omit 'аз' in casual speech since verb endings make the subject clear. Using it can add emphasis or formality
linguistic_note: Pronunciation: [az]. Short vowel. Can be elided in rapid speech. No case changes in modern Bulgarian (unlike Russian). Used for emphasis: 'АЗ казвам' (I'M the one saying)

notes_bg_to_de: Немското 'du' се използва с приятели, семейство и деца. Винаги с малка буква (освен в писма). При запознанство питайте 'Können wir per Du sein?' преди да преминете на 'du'.
notes_de_to_bg: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Ти' = 'du'. Betonung: ТИ (einsilbig). Informelle Form für Freunde, Familie, Kinder. Formal ist 'вие' (Sie). Unterschied wichtig in bulgarischer Kultur - Höflichkeit zeigen!
etymology: From Proto-Slavic *ty (you sg.). Related to Russian ты, Latin tu, English thou
cultural_note: Bulgarians use 'ти' with friends, family, children, and often with peers. Using 'вие' (formal you) shows respect to elders, strangers, or in business contexts
linguistic_note: Pronunciation: [ti]. Short vowel. Often dropped in speech like 'аз'. Dative/accusative form is 'ти': 'Давам ти книгата' (I give you the book)

notes: Third person singular masculine personal pronoun
notes_bg_to_de: Немското 'er' се отнася само за лица от мъжки род и предмети с мъжки член 'der'. Склонява се: Nominativ 'er', Akkusativ 'ihn', Dativ 'ihm'.
notes_de_to_bg: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Той' = 'er'. Betonung: ТОЙ (einsilbig, Diphthong). Nur für männliche Personen und Tiere. Bulgarische Nomen haben Genus, aber Pronomen ändern sich nicht nach Fall.
etymology: From Proto-Slavic *tъ (that one, he). Related to Russian тот, Old Church Slavonic тъ
cultural_note: Bulgarian uses 'той' for any masculine noun, whether animate or inanimate. Gender is grammatical, not always biological
linguistic_note: Pronunciation: [tɔɪ̯]. Diphthong sound. No case changes in modern Bulgarian. Full forms: той (he), тя (she), то (it), те (they)

examples.sentence: Виждам го всеки ден. (го = него, той)

notes: Third person singular feminine personal pronoun
notes_bg_to_de: Немското 'sie' (малка буква) за тя се различава от 'Sie' (голяма буква) за Вие (учтива форма). Склонява се: Nominativ 'sie', Akkusativ 'sie', Dativ 'ihr'.
notes_de_to_bg: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Тя' = 'sie' (klein). Betonung: ТЯ (einsilbig). Nur für feminine Substantive (Personen und Dinge). Objektform 'я': 'Виждам я' (Ich sehe sie).
etymology: From Proto-Slavic *ta (that one, she). Feminine form of demonstrative/personal pronoun
cultural_note: Bulgarian feminine pronoun is straightforward - used for all feminine nouns regardless of whether they refer to people or things
linguistic_note: Pronunciation: [tʲa]. Palatalized 't' + 'a'. Short forms: я (accusative: her), ѝ/й (dative: to her). Example: 'Давам ѝ книга' (I give her a book)

notes: Third person singular neuter personal pronoun
notes_bg_to_de: Немското 'es' се отнася за среден род 'das' и за безлични изрази: 'Es regnet' (Вали дъжд), 'Es ist kalt' (Студено е). Склонява се: Nominativ/Akkusativ 'es', Dativ 'ihm'.
notes_de_to_bg: Für Deutschsprachige: 'То' = 'es'. Betonung: ТО (einsilbig). Für neutrale Substantive und Konzepte. Weniger häufig als 'той/тя' in Umgangssprache. Objektform: 'го'.
etymology: From Proto-Slavic *to (that, it). Neuter form of demonstrative pronoun
cultural_note: Bulgarian uses 'то' for neuter nouns and for children when gender is not specified or known. Less common than German 'es' in daily speech
linguistic_note: Pronunciation: [tɔ]. Short 'o'. Short form: го (accusative: it). Example: 'Виждам го' (I see it). Modern Bulgarian tends to use 'то' less than German 'es'
